name: 1623_A. Robot Cleaner
description:
A robot cleaner is placed on the floor of a rectangle room, surrounded by walls. The floor consists of n rows and m columns. The rows of the floor are numbered from 1 to n from top to bottom, and columns of the floor are numbered from 1 to m from left to right. The cell on the intersection of the r-th row and the c-th column is denoted as (r,c). The initial position of the robot is (r_b, c_b).

In one second, the robot moves by dr rows and dc columns, that is, after one second, the robot moves from the cell (r, c) to (r + dr, c + dc). Initially dr = 1, dc = 1. If there is a vertical wall (the left or the right walls) in the movement direction, dc is reflected before the movement, so the new value of dc is -dc. And if there is a horizontal wall (the upper or lower walls), dr is reflected before the movement, so the new value of dr is -dr.

Each second (including the moment before the robot starts moving), the robot cleans every cell lying in the same row or the same column as its position. There is only one dirty cell at (r_d, c_d). The job of the robot is to clean that dirty cell.

<image> Illustration for the first example. The blue arc is the robot. The red star is the target dirty cell. Each second the robot cleans a row and a column, denoted by yellow stripes.

Given the floor size n and m, the robot's initial position (r_b, c_b) and the dirty cell's position (r_d, c_d), find the time for the robot to do its job.

Input

Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4). Description of the test cases follows.

A test case consists of only one line, containing six integers n, m, r_b, c_b, r_d, and c_d (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 100, 1 ≤ r_b, r_d ≤ n, 1 ≤ c_b, c_d ≤ m) — the sizes of the room, the initial position of the robot and the position of the dirt cell.

Output

For each test case, print an integer — the time for the robot to clean the dirty cell. We can show that the robot always cleans the dirty cell eventually.

Example

Input


5
10 10 6 1 2 8
10 10 9 9 1 1
9 8 5 6 2 1
6 9 2 2 5 8
2 2 1 1 2 1


Output


7
10
9
3
0

Note

In the first example, the floor has the size of 10× 10. The initial position of the robot is (6, 1) and the position of the dirty cell is (2, 8). See the illustration of this example in the problem statement.

In the second example, the floor is the same, but the initial position of the robot is now (9, 9), and the position of the dirty cell is (1, 1). In this example, the robot went straight to the dirty cell and clean it. 

<image>

In the third example, the floor has the size 9 × 8. The initial position of the robot is (5, 6), and the position of the dirty cell is (2, 1). 

<image>

In the fourth example, the floor has the size 6 × 9. The initial position of the robot is (2, 2) and the position of the dirty cell is (5, 8). 

<image>

In the last example, the robot was already standing in the same column as the dirty cell, so it can clean the cell right away.
repair_prompt:
A cleaning robot finds itself positioned on the ground of a rectangular chamber, enclosed by walls. The floor consists of n rows and m columns. The rows of the floor are numbered from 1 to n from top to bottom, and columns of the floor are numbered from 1 to m from left to right. The cell at the intersection of the r-th row and the c-th column is denoted as (r,c). It is important to understand this notation. The initial position of the robot is (r_b, c_b).

In one second, the robot moves by dr rows and dc columns, that is, after one second, the robot moves from the cell (r, c) to (r + dr, c + dc). Initially dr = 1, dc = 1. If there is a vertical wall (the left or the right walls) in the movement direction, dc is reflected before the movement, so the new value of dc is -dc. And if there is a horizontal wall (the upper or lower walls), dr is reflected before the movement, so the new value of dr is -dr.

Each second (including the moment before the robot starts moving), the robot cleans every cell lying in the same row or the same column as its position. There is only one dirty cell at (r_d, c_d). The job of the robot is to clean that dirty cell.

<image> Illustration for the first example. The blue arc is the robot. The red star is the target dirty cell. Each second the robot cleans a row and a column, denoted by yellow stripes.

Given the floor size n and m, the robot's initial position (r_b, c_b) and the dirty cell's position (r_d, c_d), calculate the time for the robot to accomplish its task.

Input

Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4). Description of the test cases follows.

A test case consists of only one line, containing six integers n, m, r_b, c_b, r_d, and c_d (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 100, 1 ≤ r_b, r_d ≤ n, 1 ≤ c_b, c_d ≤ m) — the sizes of the room, the initial position of the robot and the position of the dirt cell.

Output

For each test case, print an integer — the time for the robot to clean the dirty cell. We can show that the robot always cleans the dirty cell eventually.

Example

Input


5
10 10 6 1 2 8
10 10 9 9 1 1
9 8 5 6 2 1
6 9 2 2 5 8
2 2 1 1 2 1


Output


7
10
9
3
0

Note

In the first example, the floor has the size of 10× 10. The initial position of the robot is (6, 1) and the position of the dirty cell is (2, 8). See the illustration of this example in the problem statement.

In the second example, the floor is the same, but the initial position of the robot is now (9, 9), and the position of the dirty cell is (1, 1). In this example, the robot went straight to the dirty cell and clean it. 

<image>

In the third example, the floor has the size 9 × 8. The initial position of the robot is (5, 6), and the position of the dirty cell is (2, 1). 

<image>

In the fourth example, the floor has the size 6 × 9. The initial position of the robot is (2, 2) and the position of the dirty cell is (5, 8). 

<image>

In the last example, the robot was already standing in the same column as the dirty cell, so it can clean the cell right away. 


-------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format. Input must be taken from standard input and output must be given to standard output. The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.
completion:
def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    results = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        m = int(data[index + 1])
        r_b = int(data[index + 2])
        c_b = int(data[index + 3])
        r_d = int(data[index + 4])
        c_d = int(data[index + 5])
        index += 6
        
        # Calculate the time to reach the dirty cell
        # Time to reach the same row or column as the dirty cell
        time_to_row = 0
        time_to_col = 0
        
        if r_b <= r_d:
            time_to_row = r_d - r_b
        else:
            time_to_row = (n - r_b) + (n - r_d)
        
        if c_b <= c_d:
            time_to_col = c_d - c_b
        else:
            time_to_col = (m - c_b) + (m - c_d)
        
        # The time to clean the dirty cell is the minimum of the two times
        results.append(str(min(time_to_row, time_to_col)))
    
    # Print all results for each test case
    print("\n".join(results))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()
completions:
def cleaning_robot():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    t = int(data[0])
    index = 1
    results = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        m = int(data[index + 1])
        r_b = int(data[index + 2])
        c_b = int(data[index + 3])
        r_d = int(data[index + 4])
        c_d = int(data[index + 5])
        index += 6
        
        dr, dc = 1, 1
        time = 0
        
        while True:
            # Check if the robot can clean the dirty cell
            if r_b == r_d or c_b == c_d:
                results.append(time)
                break
            
            # Move the robot
            if r_b + dr < 1 or r_b + dr > n:
                dr = -dr
            if c_b + dc < 1 or c_b + dc > m:
                dc = -dc
            
            r_b += dr
            c_b += dc
            time += 1
    
    for result in results:
        print(result)

cleaning_robot()

main()

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    results = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        m = int(data[index + 1])
        r_b = int(data[index + 2])
        c_b = int(data[index + 3])
        r_d = int(data[index + 4])
        c_d = int(data[index + 5])
        index += 6
        
        # Initial direction
        dr = 1
        dc = 1
        
        # Time counter
        time = 0
        
        # Simulate the robot's movement
        while True:
            # Check if the robot can clean the dirty cell
            if r_b == r_d or c_b == c_d:
                results.append(time)
                break
            
            # Move the robot
            if r_b + dr > n or r_b + dr < 1:
                dr = -dr
            if c_b + dc > m or c_b + dc < 1:
                dc = -dc
            
            r_b += dr
            c_b += dc
            time += 1
    
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()

    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0

        dr = 1

        while True:

main()

def calculate_cleaning_time(test_cases):
    results = []
    for n, m, r_b, c_b, r_d, c_d in test_cases:
        dr, dc = 1, 1
        time = 0
        
        while True:
            # Check if the robot can clean the dirty cell
            if r_b == r_d or c_b == c_d:
                results.append(time)
                break
            
            # Move the robot
            if r_b + dr > n or r_b + dr < 1:
                dr = -dr
            if c_b + dc > m or c_b + dc < 1:
                dc = -dc
            
            r_b += dr
            c_b += dc
            time += 1
    
    return results

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    t = int(data[0])
    index = 1
    test_cases = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        m = int(data[index + 1])
        r_b = int(data[index + 2])
        c_b = int(data[index + 3])
        r_d = int(data[index + 4])
        c_d = int(data[index + 5])
        test_cases.append((n, m, r_b, c_b, r_d, c_d))
        index += 6
    
    results = calculate_cleaning_time(test_cases)
    
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()

def calculate_cleaning_time(n, m, r_b, c_b, r_d, c_d):
    dr, dc = 1, 1
    time = 0
    
    while True:
        # Check if the robot can clean the dirty cell
        if r_b == r_d or c_b == c_d:
            return time
        
        # Move the robot
        if r_b + dr < 1 or r_b + dr > n:
            dr = -dr
        if c_b + dc < 1 or c_b + dc > m:
            dc = -dc
        
        r_b += dr
        c_b += dc
        time += 1

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    t = int(data[0])
    index = 1
    results = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        m = int(data[index + 1])
        r_b = int(data[index + 2])
        c_b = int(data[index + 3])
        r_d = int(data[index + 4])
        c_d = int(data[index + 5])
        index += 6
        
        time_to_clean = calculate_cleaning_time(n, m, r_b, c_b, r_d, c_d)
        results.append(time_to_clean)
    
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()

def cleaning_robot():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    t = int(data[0])
    index = 1
    results = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        m = int(data[index + 1])
        r_b = int(data[index + 2])
        c_b = int(data[index + 3])
        r_d = int(data[index + 4])
        c_d = int(data[index + 5])
        index += 6
        
        dr, dc = 1, 1
        time = 0
        
        while True:
            # Check if the robot can clean the dirty cell
            if r_b == r_d or c_b == c_d:
                results.append(time)
                break
            
            # Check for vertical wall collision
            if c_b + dc > m or c_b + dc < 1:
                dc = -dc
            
            # Check for horizontal wall collision
            if r_b + dr > n or r_b + dr < 1:
                dr = -dr
            
            # Move the robot
            r_b += dr
            c_b += dc
            time += 1
    
    for result in results:
        print(result)

cleaning_robot()

main()

        while True:

            # Move the robot
            if r_b + dr < 1 or r_b + dr > n:
                dr = -dr
            if c_b + dc < 1 or c_b + dc > m:
                dc = -dc
            
            r_b += dr
            c_b += dc
            time += 1
    
    return results

    results = calculate_cleaning_time(test_cases)
    
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

        # Initial direction

        while True:

            if r_b == r_d or c_b == c_d:

Round_0.code:
def calculate_cleaning_time(test_cases):
    results = []
    for n, m, r_b, c_b, r_d, c_d in test_cases:
        dr, dc = 1, 1
        time = 0
        
        while True:
            # Check if the robot can clean the dirty cell
            if r_b == r_d or c_b == c_d:
                results.append(time)
                break
            
            # Move the robot
            if r_b + dr > n or r_b + dr < 1:
                dr = -dr
            if c_b + dc > m or c_b + dc < 1:
                dc = -dc
            
            r_b += dr
            c_b += dc
            time += 1
    
    return results

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    t = int(data[0])
    index = 1
    test_cases = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        m = int(data[index + 1])
        r_b = int(data[index + 2])
        c_b = int(data[index + 3])
        r_d = int(data[index + 4])
        c_d = int(data[index + 5])
        test_cases.append((n, m, r_b, c_b, r_d, c_d))
        index += 6
    
    results = calculate_cleaning_time(test_cases)
    
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

def calculate_cleaning_time(n, m, r_b, c_b, r_d, c_d):
    dr, dc = 1, 1
    time = 0
    
    while True:
        # Check if the robot can clean the dirty cell
        if r_b == r_d or c_b == c_d:
            return time
        
        # Move the robot
        if r_b + dr < 1 or r_b + dr > n:
            dr = -dr
        if c_b + dc < 1 or c_b + dc > m:
            dc = -dc
        
        r_b += dr
        c_b += dc
        time += 1

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    t = int(data[0])
    index = 1
    results = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        m = int(data[index + 1])
        r_b = int(data[index + 2])
        c_b = int(data[index + 3])
        r_d = int(data[index + 4])
        c_d = int(data[index + 5])
        index += 6
        
        time_to_clean = calculate_cleaning_time(n, m, r_b, c_b, r_d, c_d)
        results.append(time_to_clean)
    
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

            c_b += dc

def calculate_cleaning_time(test_cases):
    results = []
    for n, m, r_b, c_b, r_d, c_d in test_cases:
        dr, dc = 1, 1
        time = 0
        
        while True:
            # Check if the robot cleans the dirty cell
            if r_b == r_d or c_b == c_d:
                results.append(time)
                break
            
            # Move the robot
            if r_b + dr < 1 or r_b + dr > n:
                dr = -dr
            if c_b + dc < 1 or c_b + dc > m:
                dc = -dc
            
            r_b += dr
            c_b += dc
            time += 1
    
    return results

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    t = int(data[0])
    test_cases = []
    index = 1
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        m = int(data[index + 1])
        r_b = int(data[index + 2])
        c_b = int(data[index + 3])
        r_d = int(data[index + 4])
        c_d = int(data[index + 5])
        test_cases.append((n, m, r_b, c_b, r_d, c_d))
        index += 6
    
    results = calculate_cleaning_time(test_cases)
    
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

Round_0.code:
def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    results = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        m = int(data[index + 1])
        r_b = int(data[index + 2])
        c_b = int(data[index + 3])
        r_d = int(data[index + 4])
        c_d = int(data[index + 5])
        index += 6
        
        # Calculate the time to reach the dirty cell
        # Time to reach the same row or column as the dirty cell
        time_to_row = 0
        time_to_col = 0
        
        if r_b <= r_d:
            time_to_row = r_d - r_b
        else:
            time_to_row = (n - r_b) + (n - r_d)
        
        if c_b <= c_d:
            time_to_col = c_d - c_b
        else:
            time_to_col = (m - c_b) + (m - c_d)
        
        # The time to clean the dirty cell is the minimum of the two times
        results.append(str(min(time_to_row, time_to_col)))
    
    # Print all results for each test case
    print("\n".join(results))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
Round_0.report: The compilation output of the preceding code is: Code Test Passed.

prompt:
A cleaning robot finds itself positioned on the ground of a rectangular chamber, enclosed by walls. The floor consists of n rows and m columns. The rows of the floor are numbered from 1 to n from top to bottom, and columns of the floor are numbered from 1 to m from left to right. The cell at the intersection of the r-th row and the c-th column is denoted as (r,c). It is important to understand this notation. The initial position of the robot is (r_b, c_b).

In one second, the robot moves by dr rows and dc columns, that is, after one second, the robot moves from the cell (r, c) to (r + dr, c + dc). Initially dr = 1, dc = 1. If there is a vertical wall (the left or the right walls) in the movement direction, dc is reflected before the movement, so the new value of dc is -dc. And if there is a horizontal wall (the upper or lower walls), dr is reflected before the movement, so the new value of dr is -dr.

Each second (including the moment before the robot starts moving), the robot cleans every cell lying in the same row or the same column as its position. There is only one dirty cell at (r_d, c_d). The job of the robot is to clean that dirty cell.

<image> Illustration for the first example. The blue arc is the robot. The red star is the target dirty cell. Each second the robot cleans a row and a column, denoted by yellow stripes.

Given the floor size n and m, the robot's initial position (r_b, c_b) and the dirty cell's position (r_d, c_d), calculate the time for the robot to accomplish its task.

Input

Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4). Description of the test cases follows.

A test case consists of only one line, containing six integers n, m, r_b, c_b, r_d, and c_d (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 100, 1 ≤ r_b, r_d ≤ n, 1 ≤ c_b, c_d ≤ m) — the sizes of the room, the initial position of the robot and the position of the dirt cell.

Output

For each test case, print an integer — the time for the robot to clean the dirty cell. We can show that the robot always cleans the dirty cell eventually.

Example

Input


5
10 10 6 1 2 8
10 10 9 9 1 1
9 8 5 6 2 1
6 9 2 2 5 8
2 2 1 1 2 1


Output


7
10
9
3
0

Note

In the first example, the floor has the size of 10× 10. The initial position of the robot is (6, 1) and the position of the dirty cell is (2, 8). See the illustration of this example in the problem statement.

In the second example, the floor is the same, but the initial position of the robot is now (9, 9), and the position of the dirty cell is (1, 1). In this example, the robot went straight to the dirty cell and clean it. 

<image>

In the third example, the floor has the size 9 × 8. The initial position of the robot is (5, 6), and the position of the dirty cell is (2, 1). 

<image>

In the fourth example, the floor has the size 6 × 9. The initial position of the robot is (2, 2) and the position of the dirty cell is (5, 8). 

<image>

In the last example, the robot was already standing in the same column as the dirty cell, so it can clean the cell right away.
